description.text:
But how to divide that tasty,tasty treat fairly, and avoid arguments...
The usual approach; print something.
This is a simple tool used to mark a circular thing into equal-sized wedges which can then be cut with a knife.  The number wedges is imprinted on the top.

• Download the thing's scad. You will also need bezierconic.scad (thing 8931) (google it...) and FreeSerif.scad (see files associated with thing 9126).

  • Adjust the parameters; "sides" would be the most obvious one, but flange height and length are obvious options. The "locating spike" on the bottom you can probably do without.

  • print it. I suggest solid fill. Print it upside down - you'll probably end up with a mess otherwise!
    • Notes:
  • could be improved with something like triangles on the end of the flanges - these could do marking on harder surfaces.
  • the cake is a lie

A nocturnal, also known as a star dial, is an analog computer used for telling the time using the relative positions of stars in the night sky. Reference stars:
  • Pointer stars of Ursa Major
  • Kochab of Ursa Minor
  • Shedar of Cassiopeia
    • To operate:
  • Spot one of the reference stars and align the relevant constellation on the inner ring with the current date on the outer ring.
  • Sight the North star (Polaris) trough the center hole
  • With the handle pointing down, align the Pointer with the chosen reference star
  • The Pointer now intersects the current time on the inner ring!
    • NB - The customizer app seems to return an error while rendering the more complex components (Inner and Outer Rings), I'm looking into this problem but for now I have uploaded STLs for the 'Spiral' style nocturnal, and you can still customize by downloading the OpenSCAD file.

author: gonzalvo

description.text:
I needed to be able to stack my steel rims while I transport them in my car, without them scratching each other or the car. So I made theese clips, that ensures some distance between the rims, and keeps them in place. 3 clips should be enough to ensure stability. I also made a double version, to keep two rims close to each other side by side.
I did this because I need to transport 4 or them, stacked two side by side in two layers.
While not strictly nessesary, I printed an extra double clip and attached to the top rims, and used a rubber band connecting it to the lower double's bridge. That way the upper two rims don't bang into each other, and the clip stays in place :-) I designed theese for my steel rims - I have no idea if all steel rims have the same shape of edges, so I can't promise they are universal.
But I think most rims are the same. Note: The steel on the rims is only 2 mm thick, but I made the clip have a 2.5 mm space - this is to make sure it fits the rim's curve nice and snug :-) Also note that the single clips in the fotos are incorrect. I accidently printed the wrong version, where inner part of the clip isn't completely circular, and the clip "arm" is shorter.
While that is correct for the double clip, it's wrong for the single clip.
But hey, they still worked, so I didn't print the final version to correct my error.
But I fixed the mistake in the stl file available here. Enjoy :-)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Notes: Should be printed lying down, as they are in the stl file, for optimal strength. Thick layers also helps to increase the strength. I printed mine in 0.39 mm layers.

title: Dual Extruder Mount -  E3D V6 & V5 /OR J Head

description.text:
A dual extruder mounting system for a Bowden feed tube setup on a Prusa i3 with multiple versions:
  • One with an 8mm Z offset (V2).
  • One without any offset (V4).
  • One with a 6.5mm Z offset (V5).
    • The clamp will securely hold any of the groove mount extruders (16mm/12mm/16mm) such as the E3D and J-Head Style extruders with one M4 nut & bolt. The V2 files are designed to hold one of the old style Ebay J-Head Extruders from China which is (mine is anyway) 8mm taller than the new and shorter E3D V6 extruders. You should definitely check your Z Offset before printing these files as I'm sure there are many variations out there. The V4 files have no offset and are for mounting two extruders which are both the same height. The V5 files have a 6.5mm offset on the left Extruder. It incorporates the improvements made in length and slight improvements in extruder spacing (moved 2mm closer). The part was written to try and ensure that the extruders remain as true to center as possible however there is a slight offset as I needed to take into account that the old style J-Head has a slightly larger diameter heat-sink (and cooling fan mount). V2 Specs:
    Backing Plate Dimensions: 44.5mm (W) x 44.5mm (H) x 6mm (D)
    Neck Overall Length: 35mm measured from the center point of the extruders
    Neck Thickness(Z Height): 12mm
    Overall Y Offset: 41mm measured from the center point of the extruders
    Nut/Bolt Dimensions: M4 - a large range of Bolt lengths are accommodated Left Extruder Z Offset: 8mm
    Left Extruder Fan Housing Clearance: 35mm total half this from the center of the extruder
    Right Extruder Fan Housing Clearance: 30mm as above
    Clamping Collar Thinnest Wall Thickness: 6mm V3 Specs
    All specs are the same as above apart from having only 30mm clearance around each extruder (that is approx. 15mm radius from the center of each extruder). These have been removed and replaced by the improved V4 files. V4 Specs
    30mm clearance around each extruder (radius = 15mm from the center). I have updated these files (from the V3 specs) for a better fit onto the backing mount for less post print work and increased the step out (neck length) slightly to better utilize the print bed area along the Y axis. There is also a slight increase in the diameter that is cut out for each of the bolt holes. V5 Specs
    Please see the notes above.

description.text:
By using a powerful boost converter anyone who has 3s - 5s RC LiPo packs can build a mobile laptop charger.
This is a simple enclosure for the following boost converter: http://www.ebay.de/itm/231530770443?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT
Simply adjust the voltage potentiometer to the desired voltage which is about 20V for most notebooks and solder the appropriate connectors and wires. Since this converter has a constant current option for driving LEDs, the current pot has to be wound up until max so that the curent is not limited.
The device is run well below its max specs and barely gets warm, so you can print this in PLA as well. I used some drops of hot glue to secure each wire after mounting the PCB into the enlosure.

author: hh01920

description.text:
UPDATE: You might want to use the new screwless version of this design I made: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12644 A curious shape with constant width. It rolls smoothly in a square but the centre of rotation is not constant. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reuleaux_triangle More math about the Reuleaux Triangle (and the site where the cool animated gif that shows the path of the center of rotation is from):
http://mathworld.wolfram.com/ReuleauxTriangle.html

Cut the triangle and the middle frame (the thinner one) out of some opaque material (I used white HDPE) and the two thicker frames (there is only one in the dxf but you'll have to cut it out twice) out of transparent material (I used acrylic). 
Sandwich the frames with the triangle in the middle together like in the close up picture. The order in the close up from top to bottom is: top of screw (M3), first acrylic frame, spacer (to give the triangle some slack),  white HDPE frame, second acrylic frame, nut (not visible here), end of screw

I used these to help me commission my eMaker Huxley. However I am sure it they could be used for other 3D printers too.
The STLs are designed to be centered on the Huxley's 140x140mm bed so may need adjusting for other printer bed sizes.

Start with the 20x20x4mm and the adjust bed level and/or z axis as needed.
Once happy with 20mm, move on to the 40x40x4 and repeat.
I used the last 40mm with cut outs to check the quality of the prints finish.

description.text: I made this to hold 2 toothbrushes and a tube of toothpaste. To stand on shelf in the shower.
I printed it in ABS and then coated it with a clear lacquer to make it water tight.

This is a birdhouse I designed for the Birdhouse challenge. It features a unique mounting system, utilizing 1" Schedule 40 PVC pipe. It can be inserted into the base, and sunk into the ground for a simple pole mount. Using elbows and different lenghts of pipe, you can mount multiple birdhouses in many configurations, and, using my Worktable filament spool part (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:54290) you can use a short length of PVC and mount this to a tree, the outer wall of a structure, fence post, or whatever you can drive screws into. The design was inspired by the town of Griggsville, IL, with their massive Birdhouse complexes for the Purple Martins that flock there every year, and the look was styled after the dwellings in the animated series, "The Jetsons", as well as the Dymaxion Houses made from 1929 to the mid 40's. I plan on making accessories for this, even if I don't win, such as bird baths, perches, seed bin, etc. and all will utilize the same 1" PVC connection.

Print one each of the following files:
Hi-Max_Bird_Condo_Wall.stl
Hi-Max_Bird_Condo_Roof.stl
Hi-Max_Bird_Condo_Base.stl
Print at Medium Quality, .2mm layer height, 2 shells, 10% infill. other settings may still work fine. No support or raft is needed, but a raft may help when printing the roof. total printing time for me was about 11 hours to print all three parts. Changing your print speed or quality settings may produce faster results. (Hi-Max_Bird_Condo_assembly.stl is only for reference) insert a tab on the underside of the roof into a slot on the side of the wall. swing the lid closed, and while putting some pressure on the sides of the wall part, click the tab into the slot on the opposite side. the fit will be tight, as it's meant to be. Push the assembled roof/wall section onto the raised ring on top of the base part. twist slightly. Friction fit should hold the base firm, but if it's not secure enough for your liking, it may be permenantly affixed with super glue or a hot glue gun. insert a length of 1" Sch 40 PVC into the socket on the underside of base. get creative with mounting the PVC, and enjoy your new birdhouse! For a slightly more detailed assembly proceedure, refer to the Hi-Max Assembly instructions.jpg provided in the gallery.

title: Replacement wheel for a trolley bag

description.text:
This 2D model is suitable for cutting the parts of a replacement wheel for a trolley bag (wheelie bag). The wheels of different bags are probably not standardized, thus you may need to adjust the inner and outer limits of the model. The attached SVG model is suitable for the following dimensions:
  • outer diameter: 64mm
  • hole diameter (center): 22mm
  • hole diameter (both sides): 12.5mm
  • width of center disc: 9,5mm
  • width of both side discs: 6,5mm
    • Slight differences of the outer diameter or the width of the discs should pose no problem. But you should take care, that the inner diameter of the two outer discs fits to your trolley.

Material:
  • wooden panels of 6,5mm and 9,5mm thickness (or whatever is appropriate for your trolley bag bearings)
  • wood glue
    • Tools:
  • a CNC mill or a laser cutter
  • clamps (or tape)
    • Manufacturing:
  • remove all plastic parts from the axis of your broken wheel
  • measure the diameter of the metal bearing of the axis
  • adapt the 2D model, if necessary (e.g. with Inkscape - http://inkscape.org)
  • create a toolpath/GCode (e.g. with PyCAM - http://pycam.sourceforge.net))
  • command your machine to execute the GCode (e.g. with EMC2 - http://linuxcnc.org)
    • Assembly:
  • push the first outer disc into position (slightly more inwards, than necessary)
  • apply wood glue to this disc
  • push the inner disc into position; add the small break-away piece as well
  • apply wood glue to the inner disc (facing outwards)
  • push the second outer disc into position
  • clamp the three discs for some hours

author: ThePhobos

title: QU-BD TwoUp Z Wobble
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a QU-BD TwoUp (and other variations) modification to help reduce the Z wobble caused by the poorly supported Z axis threaded rod. This part will connect the threaded rod to part SS. This should also help correct the X Gantry sag although it will not eliminate it. The benefit of this modification over other available parts is this one does not reduce the Z travel, I find this especially important if you plan on implementing a Y wobble modification which is very likely to raise the bed.
You will need to replace one of the two screws holding part SS with a longer screw. I used an M4x16. You will also need to drill and tap a hole into the exact center of the threaded rod. I do not recommend that you do this by hand. I used a #4-40x1in screw; the holes in this printed part are intentionally undersized and should be drilled out by hand (drill bits are far more accurate than this printer). Sorry, some of the colors in the renderings are messed up; but you can see which part has been added and how it fits.

I made a poker chip/golf ball marker from the NLM's logo.
There is color in the model.  The embossed portions are blue, and the base is white.  in the middle area of the base there are blue rays, like the NLM's logo image.

Creep out the locals with a 3d printed set of glowing eyes hung in your shrubberies! Caps include gratuitous bats by faberdasher. You'll need a few extras to complete the build: Glow sticks! Any color will do, but of course red and orange would be apropos given the season. A toilet paper tube. You should be stockpiling these as a matter of general principle, but a rolled up sheet of cardboard will do in a pinch. Paper towel tubes will also work. A piece of string or wire to hang the unit. Your favorite hobby knife. Assembly's ghoulishly simple: print both endcaps, cut the eyeholes in the tube, activate your glow stick, cap, and hang. If you're not feeling particularly artistic, use the provided SVG eyehole templates to get started. BOO!

title: Improved Velleman K8200 Y Axis Part

description.text:
Basicaly if you tighten the screws on the bearings holder of Y-Carriage on K8200 (and maybe also 3D-Rag), this will change the angle of the linear bearings a bit, increasing the tension of movement. So I made this little part in FreeCAD to improve it. Now the Y-Movement is much smoother and noise reduced. The X/Y size matches perfectly, so I still can adjust the bed level. I just made it ca. 1 mm taller, so it hits the upper end of the end switch (I also plan to put a protective cover for this switch so I need more space here).
You can use the FreeCAD file to make a version with lower layed heatbed. :)
Edit: Added a version lowered by 4 mm (suffix: Low)

remixed_from.author: bubbob42
remixed_from.title: Custom trapdoor cover for the Amiga 1200

description.text:
This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:376267 I wanted a tighter fit on my own A1200 as when I printed the original part in Formfutura White ABSpro it fit ok, but there was a bit of movement and rattle. Perhaps there is some shrinkage on the ABS that causes this, if printing with PLA you might be better off with the old part. I used Blender to increase the size on this. This new part is a fraction larger to allow for shrinkage, dimensions of old and new part below: New Dimensions:
168.957mm
82.59mm
10.978mm Old Dimensions:
167.75mm
82mm
10.9mm

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

90

Notes: It printed well for me at 0.1mm and 90 percent infill on my Ultimaker 2 Extended. I used 90 percent infill as there seemed to be a big print time difference between 90 and 100 percent. I used supports on both ends of the trapdoor to allow the clips to print without turning into a mess.
Some light sanding on the clips on both ends to smooth them out a bit. 5 mins work at most.

comments.text: Nice remix! So ABS shrinks more than PLA - the original has a real tight fit when printed in PLA.
comments.author: bubbob42

comments.text:
Yes I think it does I think. This remix is a nice tight fit.
I might try printing the original in PLA and see how it looks.

author: TCD

description.text:
I needed a trainferry for my model railway. The railway is in Denmark around 1960 (my childhood). I found this one on the internet in a old artikel from 2003. It was made in wood and plasticcard, so I try to make it in 3D. It is in scale H0 (1:87) and the tracks on deck is set in correct seice for this. As work progres, I will superstructure and some fittings. I have try to make a wood plaking on the deck.The rest is up to You. The picture are from the 2003 model.
  • okt:
    Due to some problems with the rails (to close) I have made a rev. 1 to the upper hull. 2 new files added. Now with name tac.
    Added the 2 cabins marked L and R. They can be placed at both side. There is a marker in the side where to place them.
  • okt
    Today added bridge, deck and roof and 2 new kabins with marks for bridge, chiemy and ventilator. The 2 last parts will come later. There is also a picture for asembly. This is taken from another ferry due to come when complete, but kabin and higher is the same.
    • So now all parts are uploaded and You can see all parts except the lower parts of hull.
  • dec
    A user had problems with the Kahyt´s. Have uploaded 4 files to solve this. These 4 files is the Kahyt L+R sliced into roof and wall parts. So now no need for support. The files is Kahyt_(R+L)_WOROOF and Kahyt(R+L)_ROOF
    • At the moment I am work on habour parts. Will be ready before Christmas. I have just uploaded the first part of the ferry berth ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1168701 ). More parts to come.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2 mm

15%

Notes: I am printing in PLA and for Lower and upper Hull there is no need for support. Just print the lower part upside down. . Can be printed on all printers with at least a 150 x 150 mm table. This parts need support: Styrhus.stl
Kahyt L+R.stl You need to print 2 pcs of the parts: Upper_hull.......stl
Hull_a................stl
Galje.stl
The rest only 1 piece.

Model AK47 rifle, which I did for a friend a few years ago.
Friend did not like it.
The thing finally went to Warsaw Hackerspace where guys knew how to have fun with it. Elements are laser cut from plywood with a thickness of 4mm (I think it may be thicker) glued together as shown on the picture. Trigger moves if you want to, but you need to carve a little bit the middle layer to fit a rubber band or spring. There are holes to insert the shaft (m3 bolt or sth. alike).
You can also glue it simply.

I was at Home Depot the other day looking fruitlessly for 4-40 standoffs to mount my Arduino Mega to my Prusa i3 and realized I could just print my own! These use 4-40 screws and you can adjust the height in the scad file if necessary. These are relatively low profile at only 4mm tall, but they stand the board off just the right amount. Based on: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45447, but I fixed some things that weren't quite right and also increased the $fn variable since these are small parts and they weren't round anymore.

comments.text: The old standby for standoffs is to cut up a cheap biro (ballpoint pen) case.  This is cool too.

title: Vacuum insulation panel - example to see how it works - like a flat vacuum can - US patent: US 8,383,225 B2

description.text:
This is an example of one of my inventions, a vacuum insulation panel - a flat vacuum can. Normally it is formed out of two or more flat plastics, metalls, glasses etc. The two or more parts are soldered or what ever in a vacuum area. The printed example shows how strong the part is.
Also you can see how it works. A video showing the principle is here: http://youtu.be/w6KiCrRecYY I am looking for companies to make products out of this invention. If you are interested in a license to build such panels for fridges, houses, cars, truck cooling containers, skyscraper facades and more... please contact me. It is protected under US patent: US 8,383,225 B2.

Print the parts and remove the triangles aside.  
You can lay the one-pice parts one to the other and see how they give the pressure to the other.  
At the complete part you have only to remove the helping parts on the bottom.

description.text: I wasn't happy with other card/deck holder designs I was seeing (though, certainly, there are a lot to get lost in), so I made my own. The two compartments provide spaces for a deck and discards, the completely open front makes it easy to get cards in and out, and the largely open bottom and thin walls make it relatively fast to print. Holds 2.5" by 3.5" cards.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GKwRCDt2vWo Full Tutorial at: https://learn.adafruit.com/7-portable-raspberry-pi-multitouch-tablet/overview Portable Raspberry Pi Tablet
In this project, we'll show you how to build a portable Raspberry Pi 2, using a 7" touchscreen display, an Adafruit PowerBoost 1000c and a 2500mAh battery. Our 3D printed enclosure fits all of the components making an all-in-one, compact Raspberry Pi tablet. 7" Multitouch Display
In this build, we're using the official 7” multitouch display from the Raspberry Pi foundation. It features a beautiful IPS display and includes the drivers to work on a Raspberry Pi 2. The 3D printed enclosure gives you access to all of the ports. Instead of stacking all of the boards on top of each other, this design allow the components to be spread out, making a slim package. Download original design

comments.text: I had this printed at Shapeways.  The large bracket that holds all the boards together has 4 inner holes and 4 outer holes.  The 4 outer holes do not line up exactly with the RasPi 7" touchscreen, but the inner 4 holes do line up with their equivalent on the screen.  I have found that the charger board can be mounted on 4 M2.5 screws.  Anything larger will hit up against the components on the board.  The clearance between the pins on the video driver board and the RasPi is very small, take care to keep the USB port clear of the pins on the RasPi.

Two piece hinge, no pin necessary - unbreakable.  All of that is assuming you print it in Taulman Nylon Alloy 910.  When you print it, it prints fully assembled.

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes: The latch portion prints 2 mm above the bed so it needs to be supported. I used a 10% support in Simplify 3D software. I used Taulman's Nylon "Alloy 910" to print this. It's the easiest printing and toughest nylon available (without fiberglass). With my E3D v6 extruder it requires a print temp of 250c but other extruders can print it at lower temps. The bed temp was 65c. You can probably print this with other Nylons but I can't guarantee you won't have warping if you do. You can probably print this in PET but it won't take the same abuse. The part printed with Taulman's nylon is unbreakable in this use. You will pull the screws out before this hinge will break.

You will need to apply pressure to the hing to break the two parts apart and then work it in a bit to make it move smoother.  I've Printed 4 so far and all have worked.  I've been able to break it free using my fingers only. If you don't work with Nylon then PET might work but I know the PET wouldn't take the same abuse.
I used thinkercad.com to design it.  the hinge uses cones instead of a pin.

comments.text:
The mechanical design and properties of this latch are impressive.
I had difficulty getting the handle to separate from the latch.
By using a vise and a vise-grip pliers, I was able to persuade the handle to separate.
Next time I print this part, I will try applying some heat to the handle joint area.
I also use the nylon Alloy 910 filament to print the part.

title: Elliptical Gear with no center pivot

description.text: A slight remix of PerryT's wonderful Elliptical Gear set. I liked playing around with the gears connected at the off-center pivots, and thought it would look cool to remove the center ring entirely. You can find the original thing here, along with other types of connecting arms: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:37659 I've made a new oval gear with a spiral design in the middle. Check it out here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1125461

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 or 0.3 mm

Make sure the holes are smooth and pop in the pins gently. Be aware that the left and right sides of the gear have different teeth positions with respect to the hole. Thus, you may need to rotate one of the gears 180 degrees to get the right alignment. If this doesn't make sense, look at the photos below. Correct Alignment Incorrect Alignment (right gear was rotated 180 degrees)

author: mikeblock

description.text:
Student project for grades 6 - 7. Students started with original pumpkin source model then "carved" it using Tinkercad.  Printed on an Ultimaker 2 as Halloween decorations.
I printed them with orange PLA, also printed one in white and painted it (see picture).

Objectives: Create a 3D model by using negative space to carve a pumpkin. Audiences: Grades 6 - 7. Preparation: Some familiarity with Tinkercad.com is recommended. Lifting pieces off the workplane and positioning them correctly is not easy for beginners. Steps:
  • Have the students open the 3D pumpkin model in Tinkercad.com
  • Students should Lock the pumpkin model so they don't accidentally alter it
  • Students will need to add shapes and make them Holes so they will carve out the pumpkin when added
  • Demonstrate how to lift and rotate a shape if students haven't used these tools before
  • Carefully check student models for problems and allow them to make any needed changes.
  • Print the models
    • Results: Students were able to make a printable carved pumpkin model. If the carved sections are not too deep the the overhangs from the cutouts will present minimal problems when printing.

title: Combined Object Printing Plate (Alex's WIMU and strap holder)

description.text:
This OpenSCAD script combines 3 parts ("holder" from 2011-08-16_Alex_WIMUv3_belt_loop_v0.1.scad, and "top" & "bottom" packaging from 2011-08-16_Alex_WIMUv3_tyndall_generic_device_packaging_v1.3.scad) into one makerbot sized printing plate for easier manufacture and version control. At the moment this just involves renaming variables and copying and pasting code into another file. In the future it will be a script which will automatically rename identical variables, generate, rotate and space out parts for you from the specified parent .SCAD files to fit a specified build envelope. Version
  • 0.2
    Date
  • 2011-08-18
    • To Do
  • add option to add mouse-ears
  • add option for connecting struts between top and bottom in side by side mode
    • Changes from previous versions:
    v0.2
  • changed to 2011-08-18_Alex_WIMUv3_belt_loop_v0.2.scad
    v 0.1
  • First attempt combining multiple complete .SCAD files
    2011-08-16_Alex_WIMUv3_belt_loop_v0.1.scad
    2011-08-16_Alex_WIMUv3_tyndall_generic_device_packaging_v1.3.scad

• Design & assemble Tyndall 25mm mote based WIMU v3 system with 2 batteries
  • Print case with holder raftless
  • Hand finish, separating individual pieces, removing stringing and sanding mating areas slightly smooth. Pay special attention to the inner corners of the lips and holder. Constantly check fit until satisfactory mating is achieved.
  • Assemble into package using spacer item (To Be added to thingiverse as of 2011-09-06) ensuring there is enough length on battery wires. Double sided pads or small self tapping screws may be used between mote tabs and internal posts. Glue or double-sided pads may be used between mote stack, spacer and batteries if required. A small piece of moisture absorber may be added between layers if humidity in the packaging is of concern.
  • Close device into packaging carefully, ensuring wires do not get pinched or broken and also that battery disconnect switch & USB port line up with their holes correctly.
  • Check your USB cable fits correctly and charges device, You may need to file out the sides of the USB charging port slightly for certain overly large uUSB cable housings.
  • Shake packaged device and check that the internals do not rattle around. If they do they may need to be padded out on top and bottom with thin shims of paper, plastic or foam
  • Charge, test and calibrate device
    • If a tamper proof device is required a small amount of superglue or acetone may be used on the mating edges of top and bottom housings.

author: Rexchen

title: GoPro Kitchen Timer Time-Lapse Panning Rig

description.text: Inspired by GetawayMoments' egg timer-based panning rigs (http://www.getawaymoments.com/2011/07/how-to-make-cheap-and-easy-ikea-time.html), these parts will turn a cheap 1-hour kitchen timer into a time-lapse panning rig for your GoPro camera. GetawayMoments' rigs were great, but I wanted something I could attach to the hose-clamp mounts I made for my motorcycle (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:62652). I'll post more pictures and some video soon.

1) Start by picking up a cheap kitchen timer. These parts you can download as-is are specifically designed to mate with the cheapest kitchen timer I found at Walmart (http://www.walmart.com/ip/Mainstays-Kitchen-Timer-00900W/14913172), but you can probably modify them to work with any timer. 2) Print the parts in your preferred 3D printer. For GoPro mounts, I find it's best to orient the grain parallel to the tabs/slots for strength. 3) Remove the gear mechanism from the kitchen timer housing by unscrewing the one screw on the back (save the screw!) and pulling the dial off the front (it shouldn't be screwed/glued on). 4) Center the bottom printed part on the threaded screw hole on the back of the gear mechanism and line it up with the 3 alignment holes. Use the original screw from the housing to make it stay. Push the top printed part onto the dial connector on the front of the gear mechanism. The fit should be pretty snug, but I'm paranoid about losing my GoPro, so I put a dab of epoxy in there to make sure nothing comes loose. That should do it. Have fun!

author: oldfarmhand

title: Dual i3 Bowden JHead Hotend Mount

description.text:
This is a dual jhead mount for an Aluminium plate version i3.  
It allows mounting two jheads with their centres 24mm apart.  
Updated STL as the original was missing the mount holes and captive nuts. They were present in the openscad file but not in the STL for some reason. Note: Thingiverse appears to rename the files now when you download them, so if you download the scad files and attempt to render them it will not find the functions.scad or hardware.scad files and won't render the captive nut holes unless you rename the files or update the file paths in the original scad file with the new names.

Print the mount and the clamp.  
Fit 1/8BSP Pneumatic fittings to the mount (you may need to ream the hole a little). Fit 3 M3 nuts to the back of the mount (you many need to pull them home by temporarily fitting some M3 screws and tightening them up until the nuts are secure). Secure the mount to the xcarraige with two short M3 screws.  
Fit the hotends and the clamp. Secure the clamp with longer M3 screws.  
You can fit 2 x 25mm fans to keep the hotend PEEK cool. Again, secure with short M3 screws and M3 lock nuts or plain nuts with thread lock.

title: Quad JHead Adaptor for Dual i3 Bowden JHead Mount

description.text:
An add in adaptor for the Dual i3 Bowden JHead Mount that allows you to fit another two JHeads.  
Just needs some really long M3 screws! I haven't tested or printed this yet so expect it to change.
Remove the existing clamp, fit this one, add two more jheads and refit the clamp with some extra long M3 screws.

This fun item was conceptualized by a 6-year old... let me know what games you can come up with that involve dice that can change color based on which side they land on. You can also use them as an interesting nightlight or omnidirectional flashlight. I used a 14mm diameter bearing, but I'll bet something as small as a pachinko ball would work too inside the 25mm orientation sensor. Wiring came from the inner wires of a CAT5e cable. Solid copper is best. A single 370-ohm resistor near the negative terminal of the 9V battery was used in the circuit. I suggest printing in a translucent filament - but I'd be interested to see what they'd be like in solid colors too - so please share if you move forward with this project. I hope it's self explanatory how everything fits together, let me know if you have any questions. Here's a vid of the color dice in action: https://youtu.be/G7mJHtF9Zro Enjoy! October 22, 2015 update: I've made a stand so you can turn it 'off' when not in use: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1087587
